titleStmt.title: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627 : : A trick to catch the Old-one (1608)

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

publicationStmt.publisher: Thomas Middleton, d. 1627 (1580-1627) A Trick to catch the Old-one. As it hath beene lately Acted, by the Children of Paules London Printed by George Eld [etc.] 1608

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
A trick to catch the Old-one. Genre: Entertainment. Date first published: 1605. Date first performed: 1608.

sp.l: ALL is gone! still thou art a Gentleman, that is
all; but a poor one, that is nothing: What
Milk brings thy Meadows forth now?
where are thy goodly Uplands and thy
down lands, all sunk into that little pit
Lechery? why should a Gallant pay but two
shillings for this Ordinary that nourishes him,
and twenty times two for his Brothel that consumes
him? but
where is Long-acre? in my Uncles conscience, which is
voyage about; he that sets out upon his conscience,
never finds
the way home again, he is either swallowed in the quicksand
of Law quillets, or splits upon the Piles of a Praemunire;
yet these
old Fox brained -- and ox browed Uncles, have still defences
for their Avarice, and Apologies for their practises, and
thus greet our follies.
He that doth his youth expose,
To Brothel, drink, and danger,
Let him that is his nearest Kin,
Cheat him before a stranger.
And that is his Uncle, it is a principle in Usury; I
dare not visit
the City, there I should be too soon visited, by that
t horrible
plague my Debts, and by that means I loose a Virgins
love, her portion and her Virtues, well, how should a man
live
now, that has no living; hum? why are there not a
million of
men in the world, that only
sojourn upon their brain, and
make their wits their Mercers; and am I but one amongst
that Million and cannot thrive upon it; any Trick out
of the
compass of Law now, would come happily to me.
My love.
My loathing; hast thou been the secret consumption of
my purse? and now comest to undo my last means, my wits?
wilt
leave no virtue in me and yet thou
never the better? hence Courtesan,
round webbed Tarantula.
That driest the Roses in the cheeks of youth.
I have been true unto your pleasure, and all your lands
thrice racked, was never worth the
Jewel which I prodigally
gave you, my virginity;
Lands mortgaged may return and more esteemed,
But honesty once pawned, is never
redeemed.
Forgive I do thee wrong,
To make thee sin, and then to chid thee for it.
I know I am your loathing now, farewell.
Stay best invention, -- stay.
I that have been the secret consumption of your purse
shall I stay now to undo your last means, your wits? hence
Courtesan away.
I prithee, make me not mad at my own
weapon, stay,
(a thing few women can do I know that, and therefore they
had
need wear stays;) be not contrary, dost love me?
Fate has so cast it that all my means I must derive
from
thee.
From me! be happy then,
What lies within the power of my performance,
Shall be commanded of thee.
Spoke like an honest drab ifaith, it may prove
what Trick is not an Embrion at first, until
a perfect shape come
over it.
Come I must help you whereabouts left you,
I will proceed.
Though you beget, it is I must help to breed,
Speak what is it, I would fain conceive it.
So, so, so, thou shall presently take the name and
upon thee of a rich country widow four hundred a year
valiant,
in Woods, in Bullocks, in Barnes and in Rye stacks,
we will to London, and to my covetous Uncle.
I begin to applaud thee, our States being both
desperate,
they are soon resolute, but how for horses?
Mass that is true, the Jest will be of some
continuance,
let me see, Horses now, a bots on them; Stay, I have
acquaintance with a mad Host, never
yet Bawd to thee,
I have rinsed the whoresons gums in Mull sack many a time
and often, put but a good Tale into his ear now, so it come
off cleanly, and there is Horse and man for us I dare
warrant
thee.
Arm your wits then speedily, there shall want nothing
in me, either in behaviour, discourse or fashion,
shall discredit your intended purpose.
I will so artfully disguise my wants,
And set so good a courage on my state,
That I will be believed.
Why then all is furnished; I shall go nigh to catch that
old Fox mine Uncle, though he make but some amends for my
undoing, yet there is some comfort in it -- he cannot
otherwise
choose (though it be but in hope to cozen me
again) but
supply any hasty want that I bring to town with me,
the Device
well and cunningly carried, the name of a rich Widow,
and four hundred a year in good earth, will so
conjure up a
kind of Usurers love in him to me, that he will
not only
desire my presence, which at first shall scarce be granted
him,
I will keep off of purpose, but I shall find him so
officious to deserve,
so ready to supply, I know the state of an old man's
affection
so well, if his Nephew be poorer indeed, why he lets
God alone with him, but if he be once rich, then he will be
G the
first man that helps him.
It is right the world, for in these days an old man's
love to his kindred, is like his kindness to his
wife, it is always
done before he comes at it.
I owe thee for that Jest, be gone; here is all my
I wealth;
prepare thyself, away? I will to mine Host with all
possible haste,
and with the best Art, and most profitable form, pour the
sweet
circumstance into his ear, which shall have the gift
to turn all
the wax to honey; how now; o the right worshipful Seniors
of
our Country --
Who is that;
O the common Rioter, take no note of him.
You will not see me now, the comfort is ere it be long,
you will scarce see yourselves.
I wonder how he breathes, has consumed all upon that
Courtesan?
We have heard so much.
You have heard all truth, his Uncle and my Brother, have
been these three years mortal Adversaries. Two old tough
spirits, they seldom meet but fight, or quarrel when it is
calmest;
I think their anger be the very fire
That keeps their age alive:
What was the quarrel sir?
Faith about a purchase, fetching over a young heir; Master
Hoord my brother having wasted much time in beating the
bargain, what did me old Lucre, but as his conscience, moved
him, knowing the poor Gentleman, stepped in between them and
cozened him himself.
And was this all sir:
This was even it sir, yet for all
this I know no reason but
the match might go forward betwixt his wives Son and my
Niece, what though there be a dissension between the two old
men, I see no reason it should put a difference between the
two younger, it is as natural for old folks to fall out,
as for young
to fall in? A scholar comes a-wooing to my Niece,
well, he is
wise, but he is poor, her Son comes a-wooing to my
Niece,
well, he is a fool, but he is rich --
Aye marry sir?
Pray now is not a rich fool better than a poor Philosopher.
One would think so ifaith?
She now remains at London with my brother her second
Uncle, to learn fashions, practise Music, the voice
her lips, and the viol between her legs, she will
be fit for
a comfort very speedily, a thousand good pound is her
portion,
if she marry, we will ride up and be merry, --
A match, if it be a match?

stage.l: Enter at one door, Witt-good, at the

sp.l: Mine Host?
Young master Wit-good.
I have been laying all the Town for thee.
Why what is the news Bully-Hadland?
What Geldings are in the house of thine
own? answer
me to that first.
Why man, why?
Mark me what I say, I will tell thee such a tale in
thine
ear, that thou shalt trust me spite of thy teeth, furnish
me with
some money, will, nille, and ride up with me thyself
7Contra
7voluntatem 7et 7professionem.
How; let me see this trick, and I will say thou hast more
Art than a Conjurer.
Dost thou joy in my advancement?
Do I love Sack and Ginger?
Comes my prosperity deservedly to thee?
Come forfeitures to a Usurer, fees to an officer, punks
to an Host, and Pigs to a Parson deservedly? why then
la.
Will the report of a Widow of four hundred a year
boy, make thee leap, and sing, and dance, and come to thy
place again.
Wilt thou command me now? I am thy spirit, conjure
me into any shape.
I have brought her from her friends, turned back the
Horses by a sleight, not so much as one amongst her
six men,
goodly large Yeomanly fellows, will she trust with this
purpose: by this light all unmanned; regardless of her
state, neglectful
of vainglorious ceremony, all for my love; o it is a
fine little voluble tongue mine Host, that wins a widow.
No it is a tongue with a great T my boy that wins a
widow.
Now sir, the case stands thus, good mine Host, if thou
lovest my happiness assist me.
Command all my beasts in the house.
Nay that is not all neither, prithee take truce with thy
joy, and listen to me, thou knowest I have a wealthy Uncle
in the
City, somewhat the wealthier
by my follies; the report of
this fortune well and cunningly carried, might be a means
draw some goodness from the Usuring Rascal, for I have
put
her in hope already of some estate that I have
either in land or
money: now if I be found true in neither, what may I expect
but
a sudden breach of our love, utter dissolution of the
match,
and confusion of my fortunes forever.
Wilt thou but trust the managing of thy business
with me?
With thee? why will I desire to thrive in my purpose?
will I hug four hundred a year? I that know the
misery of
nothing? will that man wish a rich widow, that
has never a
hole to put his head in? with thee mine Host, why
believe it,
sooner with thee than with a Covey of Counsellors?
Thank you for your good report ifaith sir, and if I
stand you not instead, why then let an Host come off 7Hic 7et
7haec 7hostis, a deadly enemy to Dice, Drink, and Venery;
come
where is this widow?
Hard at Park end.
I will be her Serving-man for once.
Why there we set off together, keep full time, my
thoughts were striking then just the same number.
I knew it, shall we then see our merry days
Our merry nights -- which never,
shall be more seen.
Nay good Master Lucre, and you Master Hoord,
anger is the wind which you are both too much troubled
withal.
Shall my adversary thus daily affront me, ripping up
the old wound of our malice, which three Summers
could not
close up, into which wound the very sight of him, drops
scalding
Lead instead of Balsamum.
Why Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord; may I not pass
in the state of quietness to mine own
house, and answer me to
that, before witness, and why? I will refer the
to honest
even minded Gentlemen, or require the mere indifferences
of the Law, to decide this matter, I got the purchase,
true;
was it not any man's case? yes, will a wise man stand as a
Bawd,
whilst another wipes his nose of the bargain, no, I answer
in that case.
Nay sweet Master Lucre.
Was it the part of a friend: no, rather of a Jew, mark
what I say, when I had beaten the bush to the last bird, or
as I
may term it, the price to a pound, then like a cunning
to come in the evening of the bargain, and glean all my
hopes in a minute, to enter as it were at the backdoor
of the
purchase, for thou never camest the
right way by it.
Hast thou the conscience to tell me so, without any
impeachment to thyself?
Thou that canst defeat thy own
Nephew, Lucre, lap
his lands into bonds, and take the extremity of thy kindreds
forfeitures because he is a rioter, a wastethrift, a brothel
master,
and so forth -- what may a Stranger expect from thee, but
7Vulnera 7delacerata, as the Poet says, dilacerate dealing?
Upbraidest thou me with Nephew? is all imputation laid
upon me? what acquaintance have I with his follies, if he
riot, it is he must want it, if he surfeit, it is he must feel
it:
if he Drab it, it is he must lie by it, what is this to
me?
What is all to thee? nothing, nothing; such is the
gulf of thy desire, and the Wolf of thy conscience, but be
assured
old pecunious lucre, if ever fortune
so bless me, that I
may be at leisure to vex thee, or any means so favour
me, that
I may have opportunity to mad thee, I will pursue it with
flame of hate, that spirit of malice, unrepressed wrath,
that I
will blast thy comforts.
Ha, ha, ha!
Nay master Hoord you are a wise Gentleman.
I will so cross thee,
And I thee.
So without mercy fret thee.
So monstrously oppose thee?
Dost scoff at my just anger? o that I had as much
power as usury has over thee?
Then thou wouldst have as much power as the devil
has over thee.
Toad!
Aspic.
Serpent.
Viper.
Nay Gentlemen, then we must divide you perforce.
When the fire grows too unreasonable hot, there is
no better way than to take off the wood.
A word good Seignior.
How now, what is the news?
It is given me to understand, that you are a rival of
mine in the love of Mistress Ioyce, master Hoords Niece:
say
me aye, say me no.
Yes, it is so.
Then look to yourself, you cannot live long,
I am practising every morning, a
month hence I will challenge
you.
Give me your hand upon it there is my pledge I will
meet you?
O, o -- what reason had you for that sir to strike
before
the mouth, you knew I was not ready for you, and that
made you so crank, I am not such a coward to strike
again I
warrant you, my ear has the law of her side for it
burns horribly,
I will teach him to strike a naked face, the longest day
of
his life, 'slid it shall cost me some money, but I will bring
this box
into the Chancery.
Fear you nothing sir, I have lodged her in a house of
credit I warrant you.
Hast thou the writings?
Firm sir.
prithee stay, and behold two the most prodigious rascals
that ever slipped into the shape of
men, Dampit sirrah, and
young Gulf, his fellow Caterpillar.
Dampit? sure I have heard of that Dampit.
Heard of him? why man he that has lost both his ears,
may hear of him, a famous infamous Trampler of time; his
own phrase: note him well, that
Dampit sirrah, he in the uneven
Beard, and the Serge cloak, is the most notorious, usuring,
blasphemous, Atheistical, Brothel, vomiting rascal,
we have in these latter times now extant, whose first
beginning
was the stealing of a mastiff Dog from a Farmers
house.
He looked as if he would obey the commandment
well, when he began first with stealing.
True, the next Town he came at, he set the Dogs together
by the ears.
A sign he should follow the law by my faith.
So it followed indeed, and being destitute of all
fortunes, staked his Mastiff against a Noble, and by great
fortune
his Dog had the day, how he made it up ten shillings
I know not, but his own boast is,
that he came to town but
with ten shillings in his purse, and now is credibly worth
thousand pound?
How the devil came he by it?
How the devil came he not by it, if you put in the
once riches come with a vengeance, has been a Trampler of the
Law sir, and the devil has a care of his footmen, the Rogue
has spied me now, he nibbled me finely once too; a pox search
you, o master Dampit, the very Loins of thee; cry you mercy
master Gulf, you walk so low I promise you I saw you
not sir?
He that walks low walks safe, the Poets tell
us.
And nigher hell by a foot and a half than the rest of his
fellows, but my old Harry.
My sweet Theodorus?
It was a merry world when thou camest to town with
ten shillings in thy purse.
And now worth ten thousand pound my Boy, report
it, Harry Dampit, a trampler of time, say, he would be up
in a morning, and be here with his Serge Gown, dashed up
the hams in a cause, have his feet stink about
Westminster
hall and come home again, see the
Galleons, the Galleasses
the great Armadas of the Law, then there be Hoys and
petty vessels, Owers and Scullers of the time, there be
of the Time too, then would I be here, I would trample
up and down like a Mule; now the Judges, may it
please your reverend honourable fatherhoods: then to my
Counsellor, may it please your worshipful patience, then to
the examiners Office, may it please your Masterships
Gentleness,
then to one of the Clerks, may it please your worshipful
Lousiness, for I find him scrubbing in his codpiece,
then to the hall again, then to
the Chamber again;
And when to the cellar again?
Even when thou wilt
again; Tramplers of time, Motions
of Fleet street, and Visions of Holborne, here I have
fees of one, there I have fees of another, my clients come
about
me, the Fooli-aminy and Coxcombry of the Country, I
trashed and trotted for other men's causes, thus was poor
Harry Dampit
made rich by others laziness, who, though they would
not follow their own Suites, I made
them follow me with their
purses.
Didst thou so old Harry?
Aye, and I soused them with bills of Charges ifaith, twenty
pound a year have I brought in for boat hire, and I
stepped into boat in my life.
Tramplers of time.
Aye, Tramplers of time, Rascals of time, Bull beggars:
Ah thou art a mad old Harry? kind Master Gulf, I am
bold to renew my acquaintance.
I embrace it sir.
My adversary evermore twits me with my Nephew,
forsooth my Nephew: why may not a virtuous uncle have
a dissolute Nephew? what though he be a Brotheller, a waste
thrift,
a common Surfeiter, and to conclude a beggar, must
sin in him, call up shame in me: since we have
no part in
their follies, why should we have part in their
infamies? for
my strict hand toward his mortgage that I deny not, I
I had an Uncles pennyworth: let me see, half in half, true,
I saw neither hope of his reclaiming, nor comfort in his
being, and was it not then better bestowed upon his Uncle,
than upon one of his Aunts, I need not say bawd, for
knows what Aunt stands for in the last Translation
now sir.
There is a Country Serving-man sir, attends to speak
with your worship.
I am at best leisure now, send him in to me;
Bless your venerable worship.
Welcome good fellow.
He calls me thief at first sight, yet he little thinks I
am an Host?
What is thy business with me?
Faith sir, I am sent from my Mistress to any sufficient
Gentleman indeed, to ask advise upon a doubtful point,
it is
indifferent sir, to whom I come,
for I know none, nor did my
Mistress direct me to any particular man, for she is as
mere a
stranger here as myself, only I found
your worship within,
and it is a thing I ever loved sir
to be dispatched as soon as I can:
A good blunt honesty, I like him well what is thy Mistress?
Ifaith a Country Gentlewoman and a widow sir, yesterday
was the first flight of us, but now she intends to stay
till a
little Term business be ended,
Her name I prithee?
It runs there in the writings sir, among her Lands,
widow Meddler?
Meddler? mass have I never heard of
that widow?
Yes, I warrant you, have you sir, not the rich widow
in Staffordshire:
Gods me, there it is indeed, thou hast put me into memory,
there is a widow indeed, ah that I were a bachelor
No doubt your worship might do much then, but she is
fairly promised to a bachelor already.
Ah what is he I prithee?
A Country Gentleman too, one whom
your worship
knows not I am sure: has spent some few follies in his
youth,
but marriage by my faith begins to call him home, my
loves him sir, and love covers faults you know, one master
Wit-good
if ever you have heard of the
Gentleman:
Ha? Wit-good sayst thou?
That is his name indeed sir; my Mistress is like to
bring
him to a goodly seat yonder, four hundred a year by my
faith,
But I pray take me with you.
Aye sir?
What Countryman might this young Wit-good be?
A Lestershire gentleman sir.
My Nephew, by'th'mass my Nephew, I will fetch out
more of this ifaith, a simple Country fellow, I will work it
out of
him, and is that Gentleman sayst thou presently to
her?
Ifaith he brought her up to town sir, has the best
card
in all the bunch for it, her heart: and I know my
Mistress will be
married, ere she go down, nay I will swear that,
for she is none
of those widows that will go down first, and be
married after,
she hates that I can tell you sir.
By my faith sir, she is like to have a proper
Gentleman
and a comely, I will give her that gift?
Why does your worship know him sir?
I know him! does not all the world know him, can a
man of such exquisite qualities be hid under a bushel?
Then your worship may save me a labour, for I had
charge given me to enquire after him.
Enquire of him? if I might counsel thee, thou shouldest
never trouble thyself further, enquire
of him of no more but of
me, I will fit thee? I grant he has been youthful, but is
he not
now reclaimed; mark you that sir, has not your Mistress
think
you been wanton in her youth? if men be wags, are
there
not women wagtails?
No doubt sir:
Does not he return wisest, that comes home whipped with
his own follies.
Why very true sir.
The worst report you can hear of him I can tell you
is that he has been a kind Gentleman, a liberal and a
worthy,
who but lusty Wit-good, thrice Noble Wit-good.
Since your worship has so much knowledge in him,
can you resolve me Sir what his living might be, my duty
binds me sir to have a care of my mistress estate, she has
been
ever a good mistress to me though I
say it, many wealthy Suitors
has she Non suited for his sake, yet though her Love be
so fixed, a man cannot tell whether his Non performance
may help to remove it sir; he makes us believe he has
lands
and living.
Who young master Wit-good! why believe it he has
as goodly a fine living out yonder, what do you call the
place?
Nay I know not ifaith.
Hum, see like a Beast if I have not forgot the name,
poh, and out yonder again, goodly
grown woods and fair
meadows, pox on it, I can never
hit of that place neither,
he; why he is Wit-good of Wit-good-Hall, he, an unknow
thing.
Is he so sir, to see how rumour will alter, trust me
sir we
heard once he had no lands, but all lay mortgaged to an
he has in town here.
Push, it is a tale, it is a tale.
I can assure you sir it was credibly reported to my Mistress.
Why do you think ifaith he was ever
so simple to
mortgage his lands to his Uncle? or his uncle so
take the extremity of such a mortgage.
That was my saying still sir.
Poh, never think it.
Yet that report goes currant.
Nay then you urge me,
Cannot I tell that best that am his Uncle,
How sir! what have I done.
Why how now in a Swoon, man.
Is your worship his Uncle sir.
Can that be any harm to you sir.
I do beseech your sir do me the favour to conceal it,
what a Beast was I to utter so much: pray sir do me
the
kindness to keep it in, I shall have my coat pulled
over my
ears, if it should be known, for the truth is if it please
your
worship, to prevent much rumour and many suitors, they
intend to be married very suddenly
and privately.
And dost thou think it stands with my Judgment
to do them injury, must I needs say the knowledge of this
marriage comes from thee? am I a fool at fifty four? do I
lack subtlety now that have got all my wealth by it?
there is
a leash of Angels for thee, come let me woo thee, speak
where
lie they?
So I might have no anger sir --
Passion of me not a jot, prithee come.
I would not have it known it came by my
means, --
Why am I a man of wisdom?
I dare trust your worship sir, but I am a stranger to your
house, and to avoid all Intelligencers I desire your
ear.
This fellow is worth a matter of trust -- come sir, why
now thou art an honest lad: ah sirrah Nephew?
Please you sir now I have begun with your worship
when shall I attend, for your advice upon that
doubtful pint,
I must come warily now.
Tut, fear thou nothing, tomorrows evening shall resolve
the doubt.
The time shall cause my attendance.
Fare thee well: there is more true honesty in such a
Country Serving-man, then in a hundred of our cloak
companions,
I may well call them companions, for since blue coats
have been turned into cloaks, we can scarce know the man
from the Master -- George --
Anon sir?
List hither, -- keep the place secret, commend me to
my Nephew, I know no cause tell him but he might see his
Uncle?
I will sir.
And do you hear sir, take heed you use him with
respect and duty.
Here is a strange alteration, one day he must be turned out
like a Beggar, and now he must be called in like a
Knight!
Ah Sirrah, that rich widow, four hundred a year, beside I hear
she lays Claim to a title of a hundred more, this falls
that he should bear a Grudge to me now being likely
prove so rich, what is it trow that he makes me a
Stranger for?
hum, I hope he has not so much wit to apprehend that
I cozened
him, he deceives me then? good heaven, who would have
thought, it would ever have come to
this pass, -- yet he is a
proper Gentleman ifaith, give him his due -- marry that is
his
Mortgage, but that I never mean
to give him, I will make him rich
enough in words if that be
good, and if it come to a piece of
money I will not greatly stick for it, there may be hope
some of
the widows lands too, may one day fall upon me if things
be carried wisely: now sir, where is he?
He desires your worship to hold him excused, he has such
weighty Business it commands him wholly from all men.
Were those my Nephews words?
Yes indeed sir.
When men grow rich they grow proud too, I perceive
that, he would not have sent me such an answer once
within
this twelve-month, see what it is when a man is come to his
lands,
return to him again sir, tell him
his Uncle desires his company
for an hour, I will trouble him but an hour say, it is
for his own
good tell him, and do you hear sir, put worship upon him, go
to, do as I bid you, he is like to be a Gentleman of
worship
very shortly.
This is good sport ifaith.
Troth he uses his Uncle, discourteously now, can he tell
what I may do for him, Goodness may come from me in a
minute
that comes not in Seven year
again, he knows my humour
I am not so usually good, it is no small thing
from me, he may know that, and he will; the chief
cause that
invites me to do him most good, is the sudden astonishing
of
old Hoord my Adversary, how pale his malice will look at
my Nephews Advancement, with what a dejected Spirit he
will behold his Fortunes, whom but
last day, he proclaimed
Rioter, Penurious Makeshift, despised Brothel Master; ha,
ha, it will do me more secret Joy than my last purchase,
more
precious comfort than all these widows Revenues, --
Now Sir. --
With much entreaty he is at length come sir,
O Nephew, let me salute you sir, you are welcome Nephew
Uncle I thank you.
You have a fault Nephew, you are a Stranger here, well Heaven
give you joy.
Of what sir?
Ha, we can hear.
You might have known your Uncles house ifaith, you and
your widow, go to, you were to blame; If I may tell you
so without offence.
How could you hear of that sir?
O pardon me.
It was your will to have it kept from me I perceive now.
Not for any defect of Love I protest Uncle.
O it was Unkindness Nephew, fie, fie, fie.
I am sorry you take it in that sense sir.
Poh, you cannot colour it ifaith Nephew.
Will you but hear what I can say in my just excuse sir,
Yes faith will I, and welcome.
You that know my danger in the City sir so well,
how
great my debts are, and how extreme my Creditors could not
out of your pure judgment sir, have wished us hither.
Mass a firm reason indeed.
Else my Uncles house, why it had been the
only make --
Match --
Nay and thy credit.
My credit? nay my countenance, push, nay I know uncle
you would have wrought it so by your wit you would have
made her believe in time the whole house had been mine --
Aye and most of the goods too --
La you there; well, let them all prate what they will there
is
nothing like the bringing of a widow to ones Uncles
house.
Nay let Nephews be ruled as they list, they shall find
their Uncles house, the most natural place when all is done.
There they may be bold.
Life, they may do anything there
man, and fear neither
Beadle nor Summoner, an Uncles house! a very coal harbour?
Sirrah, I will touch thee near now, hast thou so much
interest in thy
widow, that by a token thou couldst presently send
for her?
Troth I think I can uncle.
Go to, let me see that?
Pray command one of your men hither Uncle.
George?
Here sir.
Attend my Nephew? I love a-life to prattle with a rich
widow, it is pretty methinks when our tongues go together,
and then to promise much and perform little; I love
that sport
a-life ifaith, yet I am in the mood now to do my Nephew
some
good, if he take me handsomely: what have you dispatched?
I have sent sir?
Yet I must condemn you of unkindness Nephew.
Heaven forbid Uncle?
Yes faith must I; say your debts be many, your creditors
importunate, yet the kindness of a thing is all Nephew,
you might have sent me close word of it, without the least
danger,
or prejudice to your fortunes.
Troth I confess it Uncle, I was to blame there, but indeed
my intent was to have clapped it up suddenly, and so
have
broke forth like a joy to my friends, and a wonder to
the
world, beside there is a trifle of a forty pound matter toward
the setting of me forth, my friends should
never have known
of it, I meant to make shift for that myself.
How Nephew? let me not hear such a word
again, I beseech
you, -- shall I be beholding to you?
To me alas, what do you mean Uncle?
I charge you upon my love: you trouble nobody
but myself.
You have no reason for that Uncle.
Troth I will never be friends with
you while you live if
you do.
Nay if you say so Uncle, here is my hand, I will not
do it --
Why well said, there is some hope in thee when thou
wilt be ruled, I will make it up fifty faith, because I
see thee so reclaimed;
peace, here comes my wife with Sam her other husbands
Son.
Good Aunt --
Cousin Wit-good? I rejoice in my salute, you are most
welcome
to this Noble City governed with the sword in the
Scabbard,
And the wit in the pommel, good Master Sam freedom
I return the salute.
By'th'mass she is coming wife, let me see now how
thou wilt entertain her.
I hope I am not to learn sir, to entertain a widow,
it is not so long ago since I was one myself?
Uncle?
She is come indeed?
My Uncle was desirous to see you widow, and I presumed
to invite you.
The presumption was nothing Master Wit-good, is this
yours Uncle sir?
Marry am I sweet widow, and his good Uncle he shall
find me, I by this smack that I give thee, thou art
welcome, wife,
bid the widow welcome the same way again.
I am a Gentleman now too, by my fathers occupation,
and I see no reason but I may kiss a widow by my
Fathers
Copy, truly I think the Charter is not against it, surely
these
are the words, the Son once a Gentleman, may revel it,
though
his father were a dauber, it is about the 15 page, -- I will
to her --
You are not very busy now, a word with thee sweet
widow --
Gods nigs, I was never so
disgraced, since the hour
my mother whipped me.
Beside, I have no child of mine own
to care for, she is
my second wife, old, past bearing, clap sure to him widow,
he is
like to be my heir I can tell you?
Is he so sir?
He knows it already and the knave is proud of it, jolly
rich widows have been offered him here in the City, great
wives, and do you think he would once look upon them?
forsooth he will none, you are beholding to him in the
Country then;
ere we could be, nay, I will hold a wager widow if he
were once
known to be in town, he would be presently sought
after,
nay and happy were they, that could catch him first.
I think so?
O, there would be such running to and fro widow, he
should not pass the streets for them: he would be took
up on one
great house or other presently, fah, they know he has it and
must
have it; you see this house here widow, this house and all
comes to him, goodly Rooms ready furnished, sealed with
plaster
of paris, and all hung above with cloth of arras, Nephew!
Sir --
Show the widow your house, carry her into all the
Rooms, and bid her welcome, -- you shall see widdow --
Nephew?
-- strike all sure above if thou beest a good boye -- ah --
Alas sir, I know not how she would take it:
The right way I warrant thee, a pox, art an ass, would I
were in thy stead, get you up, I am ashamed of you,
so: let them
agree as they will now? many a match has been struck up
in my
house in this fashion, let them try all manner of ways
still there is
nothing like an Uncles house to strike the stroke in,
-- I will hold
my wife in talk a little, now Gimnee; your son there goes
a-wooing
to a poor Gentlewoman but of a thousand portion, see
my Nephew, a lad of less hope, strikes at four hundred a
in good Rubbish.
Well we must do as we may sir.
I will have his money ready told for him, again he come
down, let me see too, by'th'mass I must present the widow
with some Jewel, a good piece of plate or such a device, it
hearten her on well, I have a very fair standing cup, and
a good
hie standing cup will please a widow above all other pieces.
Do you mock us with your Nephew, I have a plot in
my head son, ifaith husband to cross you.
Is it a tragedy plot, or a comedy plot, good mother.
It is a plot shall vex him, I charge you of my blessing
Son Sam, that you presently withdraw the Action of your
love from Master Hoords Niece.
How mother.
Nay I have a plot in my head ifaith, here take this chain
of gold and this fair diamond, dog me the widow home to
her lodging, and at thy best opportunity fasten them both
her -- nay I have a Reach, I can tell you thou art known
what
thou art son among the right worshipful; all the twelve
companies.
Truly I thank them for it.
He, he is a scab to thee, and so certify her, thou
hast two
hundred a year of thyself, beside thy good parts -- a proper
person and a lovely, if I were a widow I could find in my
heart
to have thee myself, soon, aye, from them all.
Thank you for your good will mother, but indeed
I had rather have a Stranger: and if I woo her not in
that Violent
fashion, that I will make her be glad to take these
gifts ere I
leave her, let me never be called
the heir of your body.
Nay I know there is enough in you
son if you once
come to put if forth.
I will quickly make a Bolt, or a shaft of it.
Faith Master Hoord, I have bestowed many months in
the Suite of your Niece, such was the dear love I
ever bore to
her virtues, but since she hath so extremely denied
me, I have
to lay out for my fortunes elsewhere.
Heaven forbid but you should sir, I ever
told you my
Niece stood otherwise affected.
I must confess you did sir, yet in regard of my great loss
of time, and the zeal with which I sought your Niece,
shall I
desire one favour of your worship.
In regard of those two it is hard but you shall sir.
I shall rest grateful, it is not full three hours sir, since the
happy rumour of a rich Country widow came to my hearing.
How a rich Country widow?
Four hundred a year landed.
Yea?
Most firm sir, and I have learnt her lodging, here my
suite begins sir, if I might but entreat your worship to be
a
countenance for me, and speak a good word: for your
words
will pass, I nothing doubt, but I might set fair for the
widow,
nor shall your labour sir end altogether in thanks, two
hundred Angels --
So, so, what suitors has she?
There lies the comfort sir, the report of her is yet but a
whisper, and only solicited by
young Riotous Wit-good, Nephew
to your mortal adversary.
Ha? art certain he is her suitor?
Most certain sir, and his Uncle very industrious to
beguile the widow, and make up the match!
So? very good?
Now sir you know this young Wit-good is a spendthrift --
dissolute fellow.
A very Rascal:
A midnight surfeiter.
The spume of a Brothel house.
True sir? which being well told in your worships
phrase, may both heave him out of her mind, and drive a
fair
way for me to the widows affections.
Attend me about 5.
With my best care sir.
Fool thou hast left thy treasure with a thief, to trust a
widower with a suite in love, happy revenge I hug thee, I
have
not only the means laid before me,
extremely to cross my
adversary, and confound the last hopes of his Nephew, but
to enrich my state; augment my revenues, and build mine
own fortunes greater, ha, ha.
I will mar your phrase, overturn your flatteries,
Undo your windings, policies, and plots,
Fall like a secret and dispatchful plague on your
secured comforts,
why I am able to buy three of Lucre, thrice outbid him, let
my out-monies be reckoned and all.
I am glad of this news.
So are we by my faith.
Young Wit-good will be a gallant again
now.
Peace?
I promise you Master Cockpit she is a mighty rich widow.
Why have you ever heard of her.
Who widow Meddler, she lies open to much rumour.
Four hundred a year they say in very good land.
Nay take it of my word if you believe that, you believe
the
least.
And to see how close he keeps it.
O sir there is policy in that to prevent better
suitors.
He owes me a hundred pound, and I protest I
for a penny.
He little dreams of our coming, he will wonder to
see his
creditors upon him.
Good, his creditors, I will follow, this makes for me,
all
know the widows wealth and it is well known, I can estate
fairly, aye and will.
In this one chance shines a twice happy Fate,
I both deject my foe, and raise my state.
Why alas, my Creditors? could you find no other time
to undo me but now, rather your malice appears in this
than
the justness of the debt.
Master Wit-good I have forborne my money long.
I pray speak low sir, what do you mean?
We hear you are to be married suddenly to a rich
Country
widow?
What can be kept so close but you creditors hear of it,
well, it is a lamentable state, that our chiefest
afflicters should first
hear of our fortunes, why this is no good course ifaith
sirs, if
ever you have hope to be satisfied,
why do you seek to confound
the means that should work it, there is neither piety,
nor policy in that, shine favourably now, why I may rise
and spread
again, to your great comforts.
He says true ifaith.
Remove me now, and I consume forever
Sweet Gentleman?
How can it thrive which from the Sun you sever.
It cannot indeed?
O then show patience, I shall have enough
to satisfy you all.
Aye, if we could be content a shame take us.
For look you, I am but newly sure yet to the widow,
and what a Rend might this discredit make: within these three
will I bind you lands for your securities.
No, good Master Wit-good,
Would it were as much as we dare trust you with?
I know you have been kind, however
now either by
wrong report, or false incitement your gentleness is injured,
such a state as this a man cannot want foes.
If on the sudden he begin to rise,
No man that lives can count his enemies.
You had some intelligence I warrant ye, from an ill willer.
Faith we heard you brought up a rich widow sir, and
were suddenly to marry her.
Aye, why there it was, I knew it was so, but since you are
well resolved of my faith toward you, let me be so much
of you, I beseech you all --
O, it shall not need ifaith sir, --
As to lie still a while, and bury my debts in silence,
till I
be fully possessed of the widow, for the truth is, I may tell
you as
my friends --
I am to raise a little money in the City, toward the
setting
forth of myself, for mine own
credit, and your comfort,
now if my former debts should be divulged, all hope of my
proceedings
were quite extinguished!
Do you hear sir, I may deserve your custom hereafter,
pray let my money be accepted before a strangers, here is
pound I received as I came to you, if that may stand
in any
stead make use of it, nay pray sir, it is at your service --
You do so ravish me with kindness, that I am
constrained,
to play the maid and take it?
Let none of them see it I beseech you.
Fah --
I hope I shall be first in your remembrance after the
marriage
rites.
Believe it firmly.
So, what do you walk sirs?
I go -- take no care sir for money to furnish you,
within
this hour I will send you sufficient: come Master Cock
pit we
both stay for you.
I have lost a ring ifaith, I will follow you presently --
but you
shall find it sir, I know your youth and expenses have
you of all Jewels, there is a Ruby of twenty pound price sir,
bestow it upon your widow, -- what man, it will call
blood to you, beside if I might so much work with you,
I
would not have you beholding to those bloodsuckers for
any
money.
Not I believe it.
They are a brace of cutthroats?
I know them.
Send a note of all your wants to my shop and I will
supply
you instantly.
Say you so, why here is my hand then no man living
shall
do it but thyself.
Shall I carry it away from them both then.
ifaith shalt thou?
Troth then I thank you sir.
Welcome good master Cockpit!
ha, ha, ha? why is not this better now, than lying abed, I
there is nothing conjures up wit sooner than poverty, and
nothing lays it down sooner than wealth and lechery? this
has some favour yet, o that I had the mortgage from mine
as sure in possession as these trifles, I would forswear
Brothel
at noon day, and Muscadine and eggs at midnight.
Master Wit-good? where are you?
Holla.
Rich News!
Would it were all in Plate.
There is some in chains and Jewels, I am so haunted
with shutters Master Wit-good, I know not which to
dispatch
first.
You have the better term by my faith
Among the number, one Master Hoord an Ancient
Gentleman.
Upon my life my Uncles adversary.
It may well hold so, for he rails on you.
Speaks shamefully of him.
As I could wish it.
I first denied him, but so cunningly,
It rather promised him assured hopes,
Than any loss of labour.
Excellent,
I expect him every hour, with
Gentlemen,
With whom he labours to make good
his words,
To approve you Riotous, your state consumed, your Uncle, --
Wench, make up thy own fortunes
now, do thyself a
good turn once in thy Days, he is rich in money,
movables,
and lands, -- marry him, he is an old doting fool, and
that is
worth all, marry him, it would be a great comfort to me
to see
thee do well ifaith, -- marry him, it would ease my conscience
well to see thee well bestowed, I have a care of thee ifaith.
Thanks sweet master Wit-good.
I reach at farther happiness; first I am sure it can be no
harm to thee, and there may happen goodness to me by
it,
prosecute it well, let us send up for our
wits, now we require their
best and most pregnant Assistance!
Step in, I think I hear them.
Art thou the widows man, by my faith she has a company
of proper men then.
I am the worst of six sir, good enough
for blue coats.
Hark hither, I hear say thou art in most credit with
her.
Not so sir.
Come, come, thou art modest, there is a Brace of royals
prithee help me to the speech of her.
I will do what I may sir always
saving myself harmless.
Go to do it I say, thou shalt hear better from me.
Is not this a better place than five Mark a year standing
wages; say a man had but three such clients in a day, methinks
he
Might make a poor living of it, beside I was
never brought up
with so little honesty, to refuse any man's money
never; what
gulls there are on this side the world, now know I the
mind, none but my young master comes in her clutches,
ha, ha, ha.
Now my dear Gentlemen stand firmly to me, you
know his follies, and my worth.
We do sir.
But Master Hoord, are you sure he is not in the house now?
upon my honesty, I chose this time,
On purpose, fit, the spendthrift is abroad,
Assist me: here she comes; now my sweet widow,
You are welcome Master Hoord.
Dispatch, sweet Gentlemen, dispatch,
I am come widow, to prove those my words,
Neither of envy Sprung nor of false tongues,
but such as their deserts and Actions,
Do merit and bring forth, all which these Gentlemen well
known and better reputed will confess.
I cannot tell,
How my affections may dispose of me,
But surely if they find him so desertless,
They will have that reason to withdraw themselves.
And therefore Gentlemen I do entreat you,
As you are fair in Reputation,
And in appearing form so shine in truth,
I am a widow and alas you know,
Soon overthrown, it is a very small thing,
That we withstand, our weakness is so
great,
Be partial unto neither, but deliver,
Without affection your opinion,
And that will drive it home,
Nay I beseech you silence Master Hoord,
You are a party.
Widow? not a word!
The better first to work you to belief,
Know neither of us owe him flattery,
Nor the other malice, but unbribed censure,
So help us our best fortunes.
It suffices?
That Wit-good is a riotous undone man,
Imperfect both in fame and in estate:
His debts wealthier than he, and executions
In wait for his due body, we will maintain
With our best credit, and our dearest blood.
Nor land, nor living say you, pray take heed you do not
wrong the Gentleman?
What we speak,
Our lives and means are ready to make good.
Alas, how soon are we poor fools beguiled!
And for his Uncle. --
Let that come to me,
His Uncle a severe extortioner,
A Tyrant at a forfeiture, greedy of others miseries,
One that would undo his brother; nay swallow
Up his father, if he can
Within the fathoms of his conscience.
Nay believe it widow,
You had not only matched yourself
to wants,
But in an evil and unnatural stock.
Follow hard, Gentlemen, follow hard?
Is my love so deceived, before you all
I do renounce him, on my knees I vow
He never shall marry me, --
Heaven knows he never meant it?
There, take her at the bound, --
Then with a new and pure affection,
Behold yon Gentleman, grave, kind and rich:
A match worthy yourself, esteeming him,
You do regard your state.
I will make her a jointure say.
He can join land to land, and will possess you of what
you can desire.
Come widow come.
The world is so deceitful?
There it is deceitful,
Where flattery, want, and imperfection lies:
But none of these in him? push --
Pray sir.
Come you widows are ever most
backward, when you
should do yourselves most good, but were it to marry a chin
not worth a hair now, then you would be forward
come, clap hands, a match.
With all my heart widow, thanks Gentlemen,
I will deserve your labour, and thy love.
Alas, you love not widows but for wealth,
I promise you I have nothing sir,
Well said, widow, well said, thy Love is all I seek,
before these Gentlemen.
Now I must hope the best,
My joys are such they want to be expressed,
But Master Hoord, one thing I must remember you of
before these gentlemen your friends, how shall I suddenly
avoid the loathed Soliciting of that perjured Wit-good,
and
his Tedious -- dissembling Uncle, who this very very day
hath
appointed a meeting for the same purpose too, where had not
truth come forth I had been undone, utterly undone.
What think you of that Gentlemen.
It was well devised.
Hark thee widow, train out young Wit-good single,
hasten him thither with thee, somewhat before the hour
where at the place appointed these Gentlemen and myself
will wait the opportunity, when by some sleight removing
him
from thee we will suddenly enter and surprise thee,
carry thee
away by boat to Coal harbour, have a Priest ready and
there
Clap it up instantly, how likest it widow?
In that it pleaseth you, it likes me well.
I will kiss thee for those words, come, Gentlemen,
Still must I live a Suitor to your favours,
Still to your aid beholding.
We are engaged sir.
It is for our credits now to see it well ended.
It is for your honours Gentlemen; nay look to it,
Not only in joy, but I in
wealth excel,
No more sweet widow, but sweet wife, farewell.
Farewell sir. --
O for more scope, I could laugh eternally,
Give you joy Mistress Hoord, I promise your fortune was good
forsooth, you have fell upon wealth enough,
and there is young
Gentlemen enough can help you to
the rest: now it requires our
wits: carry thyself but heedfully now, and we are both --
Master Wit-good your Uncle --
Gods me, remove thyself a while, I will serve for him?
Nephew, good morrow, Nephew?
The same to you kind Uncle.
How fares the widow, does the meeting hold?
O no question of that sir?
I will strike the stroke then for thee, no more
days.
The sooner the better Uncle, o she is mightily followed,
And yet so little rumoured.
Mightily? here comes one old Gentleman, and he will
make her a jointure of three hundred a year forsooth,
another
wealthy suitor will estate his son in his life time, and
make him
weigh down the widow, here a Merchants son will possess,
her with no less than three goodly Lordships at once,
were all pawns to his Father.
Peace Nephew let me hear no more of them, it mads
me, thou shalt prevent them all, no words to the widow
of my
coming hither, let me see, it is now upon nine, before
twelve,
Nephew we will have the bargain struck, we
will ifaith boy.
O my precious Uncle.
Niece, sweet Niece, prithee have a care to my house, I
leave all to thy discretion, be content to dream a
while, I will have
a husband for thee shortly, put that care upon me
wench, for in
choosing wives and husbands I am only
fortunate, I have that
gift given me.
But it is not likely you should choose for me,
Since Nephew to your chiefest enemy:
Is he whom I affect, but o
forgetful,
Why dost thou flatter thy affections so:
With name of him, that for a widows bed,
Neglects thy purer love, can it be so?
Or does report dissemble: how now sir?
A letter with which came a private charge.
Therein I thank your care -- I know this hand,
Dearer than sight, what the world reports of me yet believe
not,
rumour will alter shortly, be thou constant, I am still the
same that
I was in love, and I hope to be the same in fortunes.
Theodorus Wit-good.
I am resolved, no more shall fear or doubt,
Raise their pale powers to keep affection out.

stage.l: Enter with a Drawer, Hoord, and two Gentlemen.

sp.l: You are very welcome Gentlemen, Dick show those
Gentlemen the Pomegranate there, --
Hist --
Up those stairs Gentlemen.
Pist Drawer, --
Anon sir?
prithee ask at the Bar, if a gentlewoman came not in lately?
William at the Bar did you see any Gentlewoman come
in lately, speak you aye, speak you no.
No, none came in yet but mistress Florence.
He says none came in yet sir, but one Mistress Florence.
What is that Florence? a widow!
Yes a dutch widow.
How?
That is an English drab sir, give your worship good
morrow.
A merry knave ifaith, I shall remember a dutch widow
the longest day of my life.
Did not I use most art to win the widow.
You shall pardon me for that sir, Master Hoord knows
I
took her at best vantage.
What is that sweet Gentlemen, what is that?
He will needs bear me down that his art
only, wrought
with the widow most.
O you did both well Gentlemen, you did both well, I thank you.
I was the first that moved her.
You were ifaith.
But it was I that took her at the bound.
Aye, that was you, faith Gentlemen, it is right.
I boasted least, but it was I joined their hands,
By'th'mass I think he did, you did all well gentlemen,
you did all well, contend no more:
Come yon room is fittest:
True it is next the door?
You are very welcome, please you
cloth is laid sir.
upstairs! troth I am weary Master Wit-good
Rest yourself here a while widow, we will have a cup
of Muscadine in this little Room.
A cup of Muscadine, you shall have the best sir.
But do you hear sirrah.
Do you call, anon sir.
What is there provided for dinner
I cannot readily tell you sir, if you please, you may go
into the kitchen and see yourself sir, many Gentlemen of
worship
do use to do it, I assure you sir?
A pretty familiar Priggin rascal, he has his part without
book?
Against you are ready to drink to me, widow, I will
be
present to pledge you.
Nay I commend your care, it is done well of you?
ass what have I forgot.
What Mistress?
I slipped my wedding Ring off when I washed, and left
it at my lodging, prithee run, I shall be sad without it,
so, he is
gone! -- boy?
Anon forsooth?
Come hither sirrah, learn secretly if one Master Hoord
an ancient Gentleman be about house?
I heard such a one named.
Commend me to him.
I be do thy commendations?
O you come well: away, to boat, be gone.
Thus wise men are revenged give two for one.
I must request you sir, to show extraordinary care, my Uncle
comes with Gentlemen his friends, and it is upon a making?
Is it so?
I will give a special charge good Master Wit-good, may I
be bold to see her?
Who the widow?
With all my heart ifaith, I will bring you to her?
If she be a Staffordshire Gentlewoman, it is much if I
know her not, --
How now, boy, drawer.
Hie?
Do you call sir?
Went the Gentlewoman up that was here?
Up sir? she went out sir.
Out sir?
Out sir: one Master Hoord with a guard of Gentlemen
carried her out at backdoor, a pretty while since sir.
Hoord, death and darkness, Hoord.
The devil of ring I can find?
How now, what news, where is the widow?
My Mistress? is she not here sir?
More madness yet.
She sent me for a Ring.
A plot, a plot: to Boat she is stole away.
What?
Follow, enquire, old Hoord my Uncles Adversary --
Nephew, what is that?
Thrice miserable wretch.
Why what is the matter?
The widow is borne away sir?
Ha, passion of me, a heavy welcome Gentlemen.
The widow gone?
Who durst attempt it?
Who but old Hoord, my Uncles adversary?
How?
With his confederates.
Hoord, my deadly enemy, Gentlemen stand to me,
I will not bear it, it is in hate of me,
That villain seeks my shame, nay thrifts my blood, he
owes
me mortal malice,
I will spend my wealth on this despiteful plot.
Ere he shall cross me and my Nephew thus.
So maliciously.
How now you treacherous Rascal?
That is none of my name sir.
Poor soul he knew not of it.
I am sorry, I see then it was a mere plot.
I traced them nearly. --
Well.
And hear for certain, they have took Coal harbour.
The Devils Sanctuary,
They shall not rest, I will pluck her from his arms,
Kind and dear Gentlemen, if ever I
had seat within your breasts --
No more good sir, it is a wrong to us,
To see you injured in a cause so just:
We will spend our lives, but we will right
our friends.
Honest, and kind, come, we have delayed too long,
Nephew take comfort; a Just cause is strong.
That is all my comfort Uncle, ha, ha, ha.
Now may events fall luckily, and well,
He that never strives, says wit
shall never excel.
When did I say my prayers? In Anno eighty eight when the
great Armada was coming, and In Anno% ninety nine when the great
Thundering and Lighting was I prayed heartily then ifaith, to
overthrow Poouyes new buildings, I kneeled by my great iron
chest I remember.
Master Dampit, one may hear you, before they see
you, you keep sweet hours Master Dampit, we were all
abed
3 hours ago.
Audry.
O you are a fine Gentleman.
so I am ifaith, and a fine Scholar, do you use to go
to bed Bed, so early Audry?
Call you this early Master Dampit.
Why is it not one of Clock in the morning is not that
early enough? fetch me a glass
of fresh beer.
Here, I have warmed your Nightcap for you master
Dampit.
Draw it on then -- I am very weak truly, I have not
eaten so much as the bulk of an Egg these three days.
You have drunk the more Master Dampit,
What is that?
You mought, if you would Master Dampit.
I answer you I cannot, hold your prating, you prate too
much, and understand too little, are you answered, -- give me a
glass of bear.
May I ask you how you do Master Dampit?
How do I? ifaith nought.
I never knew you do otherwise,
I eat not one pennyworth of bread these two years, give
me a glass of fresh beer, -- I am not sick, nor I am not
well. --
Take this warm Napkin about your neck sir, whilst I
help to make you unready.
How now Audrie-prater, with your scurvy devices,
what say you now?
What say I Master Dampit? I say nothing but that
you are very weak,
Faith thou hast more cony catching devices than all London?
Why Master Dampit I never deceived
you in all my life?
Why was that? because I never
did trust thee.
I care not what you say Master Dampit?
Hold thy prating, I answer thee, thou art a beggar, a
quean, and a bawd: are you answered.
Fie Master Dampit, a Gentleman and have such words.
Why thou base drudge of infortunity, thou kitchen stuff
drab of Beggary, Roguery and coxcombry, thou Cavern fed
quean of foolery, knavery and baudreaminy, I will tell thee
what, I will not give a louse for thy fortunes:
No, master Dampit, and there is a Gentleman comes a-wooing
to me, and he doubts nothing but that you will get me
from him:
Aye, if I would either have thee or lie with thee for two
thousand pound, would I might be damned, why thou base impudent
quean of foolery, flattery, and coxcombry, are you answered?
Come will you rise and go to bed sir?
Rise, and go to bed too Audry? how does Mistress Proserpine?
Faugh --
She is a fine a Philosopher of a stinkard wife, as any
within the liberties, -- fah, fah Audry:
How now Master Dampit?
Fie upon it, what a choice of stinks here is, what hast
thou don Audry fie upon it, here is a choice of stinks
indeed;
give me a glass of fresh Beer, and then I will to bed:
It waits for you above sir?
Foh, I think they burn horns in Barnards Inn, if
I smelt such an abominable stink, usury forsake me:
They be the stinking nails of his trampling feet, and
he talks of burning of horns:

stage.l: Enter at Coal harbour, Hoord, the Widow

sp.l: Join hearts, join hands, In wedlocks bands,
Never to part, till death cleave
your heart,
You shall forsake all other women,
You Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, and Yeomen.
What my tongue slips, make up with your lips.
Give you joy Mistress Hoord, let the kiss come about,
Who knocks? convey my little Pig eater out.
Hoord?
Upon my life, my adversary, Gentlemen.
Hoord, open the door, or we will force it ope,
Give us the widow.
Gentlemen keep them out.
He comes upon his death that enters here,
My friends assist me.
He has assistants, Gentlemen.
Tut, nor him, nor them, we in this action fear.
Shall I in peace, speak one word with the widow?
Husband and Gentlemen, hear me but a word.
Freely sweet wife.
Let him in peaceably, you know we are sure, from any
act of his.
Most true,
You may stand by and smile at his old weakness, let me
alone to answer him.
Content.
It will be good mirth ifaith, how think you Gentlemen?
Good gullery?
Upon calm conditions let him in.
All spite and malice --
Hear me, Master Lucre, so you will vow a peaceful
entrance
with those your friends and only
Calm conference with the widow, without fury,
The passage shall receive you.
I do vow it.
Then enter and talk freely, here she stands.
O Master Hoord, your spite has watched the hour, you are
excellent at vengeance Master Hoord.
Ha, ha, ha.
I am the fool you laugh at, you are wise sir and know
the seasons, well, come hither widow, why is it thus!
O you have done me infinite disgrace,
And your own credit no small
Injury,
Suffer mine enemy so despitefully
To bear you from my Nephew, o,
I had rather half my substance had been forfeit, and begged by
some starved Rascal.
Why what would you wish me do sir?
I must not overthrow my state for love,
We have too many presidents for that,
From thousands of our wealthy undone widows
One may derive some wit; I do confess,
I loved your Nephew, nay I did affect him,
Against the mind and liking of my friend:
Believed his promises, lay here in hope,
Of flattered living and the boast of lands,
Coming to touch his wealth and state indeed,
It appears dross, I find him not the man,
Imperfect, mean, scarce furnished of his needs:
In words, fair Lordships, in performance Hovels,
Can any woman love the thing that is not?
Broke you for this?
Was it not cause too much?
Send to enquire his state, most part of it,
Lay two years mortgaged in his Uncles hands:
Why say it did, you might have known my mind; I
could have soon restored it.
Aye had I but seen any such thing performed why it would
have tied my affection and contained me in my first desires,
do
you think ifaith, that I could twine such a dry, oak as
this, had
promise in your Nephew took effect:
Why and there is no time past, and rather than my adversary
should thus thwart my hopes, I would --
Tut, you have been ever full of golden
speech,
If words were lands, your Nephew would be rich.
Widow, believe it I vow by my best bliss,
Before these Gentlemen I will give in
The mortgage to my Nephew instantly,
Before I sleep or eat.
We will pawn our credits widow, what he speaks
shall
Be performed in fulness.
Nay more I will estate him
In farther blessings, he shall be my heir,
I have no Son,
I will bind myself to that condition.
When I shall hear this done, I shall soon yield, to
reasonable terms.
In the mean season,
Will you protest before these Gentlemen,
To keep yourself, as you are, now at this present.
I do protest before these Gentlemen,
I will be as clear then, as I am now.
I do believe you, here is your own
honest servant,
I will take him along with me.
Aye, with all my heart.
He shall see all performed and bring you word.
That is all I wait for.
What have you finished Master Lucre? ha, ha, ha!
So, laugh Hoord, laugh at your poor enemy, do, the
wind may turn you may be laughed at too, yes marry may you
sir -- ha, ha, ha?
Ha, ha, ha, if every man that
swells in malice,
Could be revenged as happily as I:
He would choose hate, and forswear amity.
What did he say wife, prithee?
Faith spoke to ease his mind, --
You know now, little to any purpose.
True, true, true.
He would do mountains now.
Aye, aye, aye, aye.
You have struck him dead Master Hoord.
Aye and his Nephew desperate:
I know it sirs I,
Never did man so crush his
enemy?

stage.l: Enter Lucre with Gentlemen meeting Sam Freedom.

sp.l: My son-in-law,
Sam Freedom? where is my Nephew?
O man in lamentation father?
How!
He thumps his breast like a gallant Dicer that has lost
his
doublet, and stands in his shirt to do penance:
Alas poor gentleman.
I warrant, you may hear him sigh in a still evening to
your house at Hyegate.
I prithee send him in.
Were it to do a greater matter, I will not stick with you
sir, in regard you married my Mother?
Sweet Gentlemen cheer him up, I will but fetch the
mortgage, and return to you instantly.
We will do our best sir? -- see where he comes,
Even joyless and regardless of all
form.
Why now Master Wit-good, fie, you a firm scholar, and an
understanding Gentleman, and give you best parts to
passion.
Come fie?
O Gentlemen! --
Sorrow of me what a sigh was there sir, nine such widows
are not worth it.
To be born from me by that lecher Hoord.
That vengeance is your Uncles, being done
More in despite to him, than wrong to you,
But we bring comfort now, --
I beseech you Gentlemen.
Cheer thyself man, there is hope of her ifaith?
Too gladsome, to be true.
Nephew what cheer? alas poor Gentleman how art
thou changed? call thy fresh blood into thy cheeks
again, she comes. --
Nothing afflicts me so much,
But that it is your Adversary, Uncle,
And merely plotted in despite of you.
Aye that is it mads me, spites me? I will spend my
wealth, ere
he shall carry her so, because I know it is
only to spite me, aye this
is it, -- here Nephew, before these kind Gentlemen I deliver
your mortgage, my promise to the widow, see it is done, be
wise
you are once more Master of your own,
the widow shall perceive
now, you are not altogether such a beggar as the world reputes
you, you can make shift to bring her to three hundred a year
sir.
By'r'Lady and that is no toy sir:
A word Nephew?
Now you may certify the widow?
You must conceive it a right Nephew now, to do you
good, I am content to do this.
I know it sir?
But your own conscience can tell I had
it dearly
enough of you?
Aye that is most certain.
Much money laid out, beside many a
journey to fetch
the rent, I hope you will think on it Nephew.
I were worse than a beast else ifaith.
Although to blind the widow and the world I out of
policy do it, yet there is a conscience Nephew.
Heaven forbid else.
When you are full possessed,
It is nothing to return it:
Alas a thing quickly done Uncle.
Well said, -- you know I give it you but in trust.
Pray let me understand you rightly, Uncle,
You give it me but in trust.
No.
That is, you trust me with it.
True, true:
But if ever I trust you with it
again, would I might be
trust up for my labour.
You can all witness Gentlemen, and you sir yeoman?
My life for yours sir now, I know my Mistresses mind too
well toward your Nephew, let things be in preparation, and I
train her hither in most excellent fashion:
A good old boy, -- wife Girnne?
What is the news sir?
The wedding day is at hand, prithee sweet wife, express
thy housewifery, thou art a fine Cook I know it, thy first
husband married thee out of an Alderman's kitchen, go to, he
raised thee for raising of paste, what, here is none but
friends,
most of our beginnings must be winked at, Gentlemen I
you all to my Nephews wedding against Thursday morning:
With all our hearts, and we shall joy to see your
mocked:
He laughed at me, gentlemen, ha, ha, ha:
He has no conscience, faith would laugh at them, they
laugh at one another?
Who then can be so cruel, troth, not I,
I rather pity now, than aught envy,
I do conceive such joy in mine own
happiness, I have no leisure
yet, to laugh at their follies.
Thou soul of my estate I kiss thee,
I miss lifes Comfort when I miss thee.
O never will we part
Until I leave the Sight of men,
We will never trust conscience
of our kin,
Since Cozenage brings that title in,
I will wait these seven hours but I will see him caught,
Faith so will I.
Hang him prodigal, he is stripped of the Widow.
On my Troth she is the wiser, she has made the happier
choice, and I wonder of what Stuff those widows hearts are
made of, that will marry unfledged Boys, before comely
Gentlemen.
News, news, news,
What boy?
The Rioter is caught.
So, so, so, so, it warms me at the heart, I love
a-life to see
Dogs upon men; o here he comes.
My last joy was so great it took away the sense of all
future afflictions, what a day is here overcast? how soon a
black
tempest rises?
O we may speak with you now sir, what is become of
your rich widow, I think you may cast your cap at the widow,
may you not sir.
He a rich widow? who a prodigal, a daily Rioter, and a
nightly vomiter, he a widow of account? he a hole in the
counter.
You do well my masters, to tyrannize over misery, to
the afflicted, it is a custom you have here amongst you, I
would wish you never leave it, and I
hope you will do as I bid you
Come, come sir, what say you extempore now to your bill
of a hundred pound: a sweet debt, for frotting your
doublets.
Here is mine of forty,
Here is mine of fifty.
Pray sirs you will give me Breath.
No sir, we will keep you out of breath still, then
we shall
be sure you will not run away from us.
Will you but hear me speak?
You shall pardon us for that sir, we know you
have too
fair a tongue of your own, you over
came us too lately, a shame
take you, we are like to loose all that for
want of witnesses, we
dealt in policy then, always
when we strive to be
most politic
we prove most coxcombs, 7Non 7plus 7 ultra. I perceive
by us,
we are not ordained to thrive by wisdom, and
therefore we
must be content to be Tradesmen.
Give me but reasonable time, and I protest I will make
you ample Satisfaction.
Do you talk of Reasonable time to us?
It is true, beasts know no reasonable time,
We must have either money or carcass.
Alas what good will my carcass do you?
O it is a Secret delight we have amongst us, we
that are
used to keep birds in cages, I have the heart to
keep men in
prison, I warrant you.
I perceive I must crave a little more Aid from my wits,
do but make shift for me this once, and I will forswear
trouble you in the like fashion hereafter, I will have
better employment
for you, if I live. You will give me leave my masters
to make Trial of my friends and raise all means I can.
That is our desires sir.
Master Wit-good.
O art thou come!
May I speak one word with you in private sir?
No by my faith canst thou, I am in hell here and the
Devils will not let me Come to thee.
Do you call us devils, you shall find us Puritans
him away, let them talk as they go, we will not stand
to hear them,
ah sir, am I a devil, I shall think the better of myself as
long
as I live, a Devil ifaith.
What a Sweet blessing hast thou Master Hoord above a
multitude, wilt thou never be
thankful? how dost thou think
to be blessed another time? or dost thou count this the full
measure
of thy happiness by my troth I think thou dost not only a wife
large in possessions, but spacious in content, she is
rich, she is
young, she is fair, she is wise, when I wake I think of her
lands
that revives me, when I go to bed, I dream of her
beauty, and
that is enough for me, she
is worth four hundred a year in her very
smock, if a man knew how to use it, but the journey will
be all
introth into the Country, to ride to her Lands in
state and order
following my Brother and other worshipful Gentlemen whose
companies I have sent down for already, to ride along
with us,
in their goodly Decorum beards, their broad Velvet
cassocks,
and chains of gold twice or thrice double; against which
time,
I will entertain some ten men of mine
own, into Liveries, all of occupations
or qualities, I will not keep an idle man about
me, the sight of which will so vex my Adversary
Lucre, for
we will pass by his door of purpose, make a little
stand for nonce,
and have our horses Curvet before the window, certainly he
never endure it, but run up and
hang himself presently? how now
sirrah? what news? any that offer their service to me
yet.
Yes sir, there are some in the hall, that wait for
your worships
liking, and desire to be entertained.
Are they of occupation?
They are men fit for your worship sir.
Sayst so? send them all in! -- to see ten men ride
after me
in watchet liveries with Orange tawny capes, it will cut
his
comb ifaith, how now? of what occupation are you sir.
A Taylor, if it please your worship.
A taylor, o very good, you shall serve to make all the
Liveries -- what are you sir?
A Barber sir.
A Barber very needful, you shall shave all the house,
and if need require stand for a Reaper in the Summer
time, --
You sir?
A Perfumer?
I smelt you before, Perfumers of all men had need carry
themselves uprightly, for if they were once knaves they
would
be smelt out quickly,-- to you sir?
A Falconer if it please your worship --
Sa, ho, sa ho, sa ho -- and you sir?
A Huntsman sir.
There boy, there boy, there boy: I am not so old but
I have pleasant days to come, I promise you my Masters I
take such a good liking to you, that I entertain you
all, I
put you already into my countenance, and you shall be shortly
in my livery? but especially you two my Jolly Falconer,
and
my bonny huntsman, we shall have most need of you at my
wife's Manor houses in the Country, there is goodly parks
and
Champion grounds for you, we shall have all our
sports within
ourselves, all the Gentlemen of the Country shall be beholding
to us and our pastimes:
And we will make you worship admire sir:
Sayst thou so? do but make me admire, and thou shalt
want for nothing, -- my Taylor?
Anon sir.
Go presently in hand with the liveries.
I will sir.
My Barber.
Here sir.
Make them all trim fellows, louse them well, especially my
huntsman, and cut all their beards of the Polonian fashion: my
perfumer:
Under your nose sir:
Cast a better favour upon the knaves, to take away the
sent of my Tailors feet, and my Barbers Lotium-water:
It shall be carefully performed sir.
But you my Falconer and Huntsman, the welcomest men
alive ifaith:
And we will show you that sir, shall deserve your
favour?
I prithee show me that: go you knaves all, and wash
your lungs in the Buttery, go -- by'th'mass, and well
remembered,
I will ask my wife that question, wife, Mistress Iane
Hoord!
Sir? would you with me.
I would but know sweet wife, which might stand best to
thy
liking, to have the wedding dinner kept here or in the
Country?
Hum? faith sir it would like me better here, here you were
married, here let all rites be ended.
Could a Marquess give a better answer? Hoord bear
thy head aloft, thou hast a wife will advance it, what haste
comes
here now? yea a letter: some dreg of my Adversaries malice:
come hither, what is the news!
A thing that concerns my Mistress sir.
Why then it concerns me knave?
Aye and you knave too, (cry your worship mercy) you
are both like to come into trouble I promise you sir, a
How a pre-contract sayst thou?
I fear they have too much proof of it, sir, old Lucre he
runs mad up and down and will to law as fast as he
can, young
Wit-good laid hold on by his creditors, he exclaims
you on the other side, says you have wrought his undoing,
by the injurious
detaining of his contract?
Body of me?
He will have utmost satisfaction.
The Law shall give him recompense he says.
Alas his creditors so merciless, my state being yet
uncertain, I deem it not unconscionable to further him.
True sir --
Wife, what says that letter let me construe it.
Cursed be my rash and unadvised words,
I will set my foot upon my tongue,
And tread my inconsiderate grant to dust.
Wife --
A pretty shift ifaith, I commend a woman when she
can make away a letter from her husband handsomely, and this
was cleanly done by my troth.
I did sir?
Some foolish words I must confess did pass,
Which, now litigiously he fastens on me.
Of what force? let me examine them.
Too strong I fear, would I were well freed of him.
Shall I compound?
No sir, I would have it done some Nobler way
Of your side; I would have you come off with honour,
Let baseness keep with them: why have you not the means
sir, the occasion is offered you.
Where? how? dear wife.
He is now caught by his creditors, the slave is needy,
his debts petty, he will rather bind himself, to all
then rot in prison, by this only
means you may get a release
from him, it is not yet come to his Uncles hearing, send
speedily for the creditors, by this time he is desperate,
he will set
his hand to anything, take
order for his debts, or discharge them
quite, a pox on him, let us be rid of a rascal.
Excellent, thou dost astonish me, go, run, make haste,
bring both the creditors and Wit-good hither.
This will be some revenge yet.
In the mean space I will have a release drawn -- within
there.
Sir.
Sirrah, come take directions, go to my Scrivener.
I am yet like those, whose riches lie in dreams,
If I be waked they are false, such is my fate,
Who ventures deeper than the desperate state.
Though I have sinned yet could I become new,
For where I once vow, I am ever
true.
Away, Dispatch, on my Displeasure, quickly, happy occasion,
pray heaven he be in the right Vein now to set his
hand to it, that nothing alter him: grant that all his
follies may
Meet in him at once, to besot him
I pray for him ifaith, and here he comes;
What would you with me now, my Uncles spiteful
adversary.
Nay I am friends,
Aye when your mischief is spent.
I heard you were arrested.
Well, what then? you will pay none of my debts I am sure.
A wise man cannot tell,
There may be those Conditions greed upon,
May move me to do much,
Aye when It is thou perjured Woman, O no name
Is vild enough to match thy
treachery,
That art the cause of my confusion.
Out you penurious slave.
Nay wife you are too froward,
Let him alone, give losers leave to talk.
Shall I remember thee of another
promise far stronger
than the first.
I would fain know that.
it would call shame to thy cheeks.
Shame.
Hark in your ear. -- will he come off thinkst thou, and
pay my Debts roundly.
Doubt nothing, there is a Release a drawing and all to
which you must set your hand.
Excellent.
But me thinks ifaith you might have made some
shift to discharge this yourself, having in the mortgage,
and never
have burdened my conscience with it.
On my troth I could not, for my creditors cruelties
extend
to the present.
No more, -- why do your worst for that, I defy you.
You are impudent, I will call up witnesses.
Call up thy wits for thou hast been devoted to follies
a
long time.
Wife, you are too bitter? Master Wit-good, and you my
Masters you shall hear a mild speech come from me now, and
this is it, it has been my fortune, Gentlemen, to have an
extraordinary
blessing poured upon me a-late, and here she stands, I have
wedded her and bedded her, and yet she is little the
worse, some
foolish words she hath past to you in the Country, and
some
peevish debts you owe here in the City, set the Hares head
the Goose giblet, release you her of her words, and I
will release
you of your debts sir:
Would you so, I thank you for that sir, I cannot
blame
you ifaith.
Why are not debts better than words sir?
Are not words promises, and are not promises debts sir.
He plays at back racket with me.
Come hither Master Wit-good come hither, be ruled by
fools once:
We are Citizens and know what belong to it.
Take hold of his offer pox on her, let her go, if your
debts
were once discharged, I would help you to a widow myself
worth ten of her.
Mass partner and now you remember me of it, there is
Master Muligrubs sister newly fallen a widow.
Gods me, as pat as can be, there is a widow left for you,
ten thousand in money, beside Plate, Jewels 7et 7caetera I
warrant
it a match, we can do all in all with her, prithee
dispatch we will
carry thee to her presently.
My Uncle will never endure me, when
he shall hear I set
my hand to a release:
Hark, I will tell thee a Trick for that, I have
spent five hundred
pound in suites in my time, I should be wise, thou art
now a
prisoner, make a release, take it of my word,
whatsoever a man
makes as long as he is in durance, it is nothing in law,
not thus
much.
Say you so sir?
I have paid for it I know it.
Proceed then, I consent.
Why well said:
How now my Masters, what have you done with him?
With much ado sir, we have got him to consent.
Ah -- a -- a, -- and what came his debts to now?
Some eight score odd pounds sir.
Nau, nau, nau,, nau, naw, tell me the second time, give me a
lighter sum, they are but desperate debts you know, near
called in but upon such an accident, a poor needy knave he
would starve and rot in prison, come, come, you shall have
ten
shillings in the pound and the sum down roundly --
You must make it a mark sir, --
Go to then, tell your money in the mean time, you shall
find little less there, -- come Master Wit-good you are
to do yourself good now, welcome honest Scrivener, now
you shall hear the release read, --
Be it known, to all men by these presents, that I
Theodorus
Wit-good, Gentleman, sole Nephew to pecunious Lucre, having
unjustly made title and claim, to one Iane Meddler, late
of Anthory Meddler, and now wife to Walkadine Hoord, in
consideration
of a competent sum of money to discharge my debts,
do forever hereafter disclaim any
title, right, estate, or interest
in or to the said widow late in the occupation of
Walkadine Hoord,
as also neither to lay claim, by virtue of any former
contract,
grant, promise or devise, to any of her Manor,
Manor houses,
Parks, Groves, Meadow grounds, arable lands, Barnes, stacks,
Stables, Dove holes, and Cony burrows; together with all
cattle, money, plate, jewels, borders, chains, bracelets,
furnitures,
hangings, movables, or immoverables in witness whereof
I the said Theodorus Wit-good, have interchangeably set to
my hand and seal before these presents, the day, and date
above
written.
What a precious fortune hast thou slipped here like a beast
as thou art?
Come, unwilling heart come.
well Master Hoord, give me the pen, I see
It is vain to quarrel with our destiny.
O as vain a thing as can be, you cannot commit a
greater absurdity sir, -- so, so, give me that hand
now, before all
these presents I am friends forever
with thee
Troth, and it were pity of my heart now, if I should
bear you any grudge ifaith.
Content, I will send for thy Uncle against the wedding
dinner, we will be friends once
I hope to bring it to pass myself sir?
How now? is it right my masters?
It is something wanting sir, yet
it shall be sufficient.
Why well said, a good conscience makes a fine show
nowadays, come my Masters you shall all -- taste of my wine
ere you depart.
We follow you sir?
I will try these fellows now, -- a word sir, what will
you
carry me to that widow now?
Why do you think we were in earnest ifaith? carry you
a rich widow, we should get much credit by that;
a noted
Rioter a contemptible prodigal, it was a Trick, we have
amongst
