us, to get in our money, fare you well sir.
Farewell and be hanged, you short pig haired Ram headed
rascals, he that believes in you, shall
never be saved I warrant
him, by this new league, I shall have some access unto
my love --
Master Wit-good?
My life,
Meet me presently, that note directs you, I would not
be suspected, our happiness attends us, farewell?
A words enough.

stage.l: Dampit the Usurer in his bed, Audry

sp.l: Let the Usurer cram him, in interest that excel,
There is pits enough to damn him,
before he comes to hell.
In Holborne, some: in Fleet street some,
Wherever he come, there is some there is some.
7Trahe, 7traheto, draw the Curtain, give me a sip of
Sack more.
Look you, did not I tell you he lay like the devil in
chains, when he was bound for a thousand year.
But I think the devil had no steel Bedstaffs, he goes
beyond him for that.
Nay do but mark the conceit of his drinking, one
must wipe his mouth for him with a muckinder, do you see
sir.
Is this the sick trampler, why he is only
bedrid with drinking.
True sir, he spies us.
What? sir Tristram? you come and see a weak man
here, a very weak man, --
If you be weak in body, you should be strong in prayer
sir.
O, I have prayed too much poor man.
There is a taste of this soul for you.
Fah, loathsome?
I come to borrow a hundred pound of you sir.
Alas you come at an ill time, I cannot spare it ifaith,
I have but two thousand in the house.
Ha, ha, ha.
Out you gernatiue quean, the mullipood of villainy,
the Spinner of concupiscency.
Yea gentlemen are you here before us? how is he now?
Faith the same man still, the Tavern bitch has bit him
in the head.
We shall have the better sport with him, peace, and
how cheers Master Dampit now?
O, my bosom sir Lancelot, how cheer I? thy presence
is restorative:
But I hear a great complaint of you Master Dampit, among
gallants.
I am glad of that ifaith: -- prithee what?
They say you are waxed proud a-late, and if a friend visit
you in the afternoon, you will scarce know him.
Fie, fie, proud? I cannot remember any such thing, sure
I was drunk then.
Think you so sir?
There it was ifaith, nothing but the pride of the Sack
and so certify them, fetch Sack sirrah.
A vengeance Sack you once.
Why Master Dampit if you hold on as you begin, and
lie a little longer, you need not take care how to dispose
your
wealth, you will make the Vintner your heir.
Out you babliaminy, you unfeathered cremitoryed
quean, you cullisance of scabiosity.
Good words Master Dampit, to speak before a maid
and a virgin.
Hang thy virginity, upon the pole of carnality.
Sweet terms, my Mistress shall know them.
Note but the misery of this usuring slave, here he lies
like a noisome dunghill, full of the poison of his drunken
blasphemies, and they to whom he
bequeaths all, grudge him
the very meat that feeds him, the very pillow that
eases him,
here may a usurer behold his end, what profits it to be a
this world, and a devil in the next.
Sir Lancelot? let me buss thee sir Lancelot, thou art the
only friend that I honour and
respect.
I thank you for that Master Dampit.
Farewell my bosom sir Lancelot.
Gentlemen, if you love me, let me step
behind you,
and one of you fall a-talking of me to him.
Content -- Master Dampit.
So sir.
Here came sir Lancelot to see you even
now.
Hang him rascal.
Who sir Lancelot.
Pythagoricall rascal.
Pythagoricall?
Aye he changes his cloak when he meets a Sergeant.
What a rogue is this?
I wonder you can rail at him sir, he comes in love to
see
you.
A louse for his love, his father was a Comb maker, I
have no need of his crawling love, he comes to have
longer
day, the superlative rascal:
'sfoot I can no longer endure the rogue, Master Dampit,
I come to take my leave once again
sir?
Who? my dear and kind Sir Lancelot? the
only Gentleman
of England, let me hug thee, farewell and a thousand.
Composed of wrongs and slavish flatteries.
Nay Gentlemen, he shall show you more Tricks yet, I will
give you another taste of him:
Is it possible?
His memory is upon departing.
Another cup of Sack.
Mass then it will be quite gone: before he drink
that, tell
him there is a country client come up, and here attends
for his
Learned advice.
One Cup more, and then let the Bell toll, I hope I
shall be weak enough by
that time.
Master Dampit.
Is the Sack spouting.
It is coming forward sir, -- here is a countryman a client
of yours, waits for your deep and profound advice sir.
A coxcombry? where is he? let him approach, set me
up a peg higher.
You must draw near sir.
Now goodman fooleaminy, what say you to me now
Please your good worship, I am a poor man sir. --
What make you in my Chamber then?
I would entreat your worships device in a just and
honest cause sir. --
I meddle with no such matters, I refer them, to Master
No-mans Office.
I had but one house left me in all the world sir which
was my fathers, my Grandfathers, my great Grandfathers, and
now a Villain has unjustly wrung me out, and took possession
of it.
Has he such feats? thy best course is to bring thy
7eiectione
7firme, and in Seven year thou mayst shove him out by
the Law.
Alas, if it please your worship, I have small friends and
less money.
Heyday, this gear will fadge well, hast no money, why
then my advice is thou must set fire to the house and so
get him out.
That will break strife indeed,
I thank your worship for your hot Counsel sir. --
altering but my voice a little, you see he knew me not, you may
observe by this that a drunkards memory, holds longer
in the
voice than in the person, but Gentlemen shall I show you a
sight, behold the little dive-dapper of Damnation, Gulf the
usurer, for his time worse than the other.
What is he comes with him?
Why Hoord, that married lately the widow meddler.
O, I cry you mercy sir.
Now gentlemen visitants? how does master Dampit?
faith here he lies even drawing --
in sir, good canary as
fast as he can sir, a very weak creature truly, here is
almost
past memory.
Fie Master Dampit: you lie lazing a bed here, and I come
to invite you to my wedding dinner, up, up, up.
Who is this master Hoord! who hast thou married
the name of foolery.
A rich widow.
A Dutch widow.
A rich widow, -- one widdow meddler.
Meddler she keeps open house.
She did I can tell you in her other husbands days,
open house for all comers, horse and man was welcome, and
Room enough for them all.
There is too much for thee then, thou mayst let out some
to thy Neighbours.
What? hung alive in chains O Spectacle, bed staffs
of steel, 7O 7monstrum, 7horrendum, 7Informe, 7Ingeni 7cui
7Lumen
7ademptum, O Dampit, Dampit, here is a Just judgment, shown
upon usury, extortion, and trampling Villainy.
this excellent, thief rails upon the Thief.
Is this the end of cut throat Usury,
Brothel, and blasphemy? now mayst thou see what Race a Usurer
runs.
Why thou Rogue of universality, do not I know thee?
thy sound is like the cuckoo, the welsh Ambassador, thou
cowardly slave that offers to fight with a sick man
when his
weapon is down: rail upon me in my naked bed? why thou
great Lucifers little vicar, I am not so weak but I know a
at first sight, thou Inconscionable Rascal, thou that
goest upon
middlesex Juries, and will make haste to give up thy
verdict, because
thou wilt not loose thy dinner, are you answered?
If it were not for shame. --
Thou wouldst be hanged then.
Nay you must exercise patience Master Gulf,
in a sick man's Chamber.
He will quarrel with none I warrant you, but those
are bedrid.
Let him come Gentlemen, I am armed, reach my close
stool hither.
Here will be a sweet fray anon, I will leave you
gentlemen.
Nay we will along with you,
Master Gulf.
Hang him usuring rascal.
Push, set your Strength to his, your wit to his.
Pray Gentlemen depart, his hour is come upon him,
sleep in my bosom, sleep.
Nay we have enough of him
ifaith, keep him for the
house. -- Now make your best.
For thrice his wealth, I would not have his breast.
A little thing would make me beat him, now he is asleep.
Mass then it will be a pitiful day when he wakes.
I would be loath to see that day, come.
You overrule me gentlemen ifaith.
Nay uncle, let me prevail with you so much,
ifaith go, now he has invited you,
I shall have great joy there, when he has borne away the
widow.
Why la, I thought where I should find you presently;
Uncle, on my troth, it is nothing so.
What is nothing so sir, is not he married to the widow.
No by my troth is he not Uncle.
How?
Will you have the truth of it, he is married to a whore
ifaith.
I should laugh at that.
Uncle, let me perish in your favour if you find it not
and that it is I that have married the honest woman.
Ha? I would walk ten mile afoot to see that ifaith.
And see it you shall, or I will never
see you again.
A Quean ifaith? ha, ha, ha.

stage.l: Enter Hoord tasting wine the Host following

sp.l: Pup, pup, pup, pup, I like not this wine, is there
never a
better Tierce in the house.
Yes sir, there are as good Tierce in the house, as any are
in England.
Desire your mistress you knave, to taste them all over, she
has better Skill.
Has she so, the better for her, and the worse for
you.
Arthur, is the cupboard of plate set out,
All is in order sir.
I am in love with my Liveries every
time I think on
them, they make a gallant show by my troth. -- Niece.
Do you call sir?
prithee show a little diligence, and overlook the
knaves a little, they will filch and steal today and send
whole pasties
home to their wives, if thou beest a good Niece, do not
see me purloined.
Fear it not sir, I have cause, though the feast be prepared
for you, yet it serves fit for my wedding dinner too.
Master Lamprey, and Master Spitchcock two the most
welcome me gentlemen alive, your fathers and mine were all free
of the Fishmongers.
They were indeed sir, you see bold guests sir, soon entreated
And that is best sir -- how now sirrah?
There is a coach come to the door sir.
My Lady Foxestone on my life. Mistress Iane Hoord, wife,
mass it is her Ladyship indeed, Madam you are welcome
an unfurnished house, dearth of cheer, scarcity of attendance.
You are pleased to make the worst sir.
Wife.
Is this your Bride.
Yes Madam salve my Lady Foxtone.
Please you Madam a while to taste the air in the garden?
It will please us well.
Who would not wed the most delicious life,
No Joys are like the comforts of a wife.
So we bachelors think that are not troubled with
them
Your worships brother with another
ancient Gentleman,
are newly alighted Sir.
Master Onesiphorus Hoord, why now our company begins
to come in: my dear and kind brother welcome ifaith.
You see we are men at an hour brother.
Aye, I will say that for you brother you keep as
good an
hour to come to a feast, as any Gentleman in the
Shire,
what old Master Limber and Master Kicks, do we meet
ifaith Jolly Gentlemen?
We hope you lack guess sir?
O welcome, welcome, we lack still such guess as your
worships.
Ah sirrah brother, have you catched up widow Meddler.
From them all brother, and I may tell you, I had mighty
enemies, those that stuck sore, old Lucre is a sore fox I
can tell
you brother.
Where is she I will go seek her out, I long to have a
smack
at her lips.
And most wishfully brother see where she comes, give
her a smirk now we may hear it all the house over.
O heaven, I am betrayed, I know
that face.
Ha, ha, ha, why how now? are you both ashamed? come
Gentlemen, we will look another way --
Nay Brother, hark you, come you are disposed to be merry?
Why do we meet else man?
That is another matter, I was never
so freed in my life but
that you had been in earnest.
How mean you brother?
You said she was your wife?
Did I so? by my troth and so she is.
By your troth Brother?
What reason have I to dissemble with my friends, brother,
if marriage can make her mine, she is mine? why?
Troth I am not well of a sudden? I must crave pardon
brother, I came to see you, but I cannot stay dinner ifaith.
I hope you will not serve me so brother.
By your leave Master Hoord.
What now? what now? pray Gentlemen, you were wont
to show yourselves wise men.
But you have shown your folly too much here.
How?
Fie, fie, a man of your repute and name,
You will feast your friends but cloy them first with shame.
This grows too deep pray let us reach the sense.
In your old age dote on a Courtesan --
Ha?
Marry a Strumpet?
Gentlemen!
And Wit-goods quean:
O, nor Lands, nor living?
Living?
Speak?
Alas you know at first sir,
I told you I had not living.
Out, out, I am cheated, infinitely cozened.
Nay Master Hoord:
A dutch widow, a dutch widow, a dutch widow:
Why Nephew shall I trace thee still a liar? wilt make me
mad is not yon thing the widow.
Why la, you are so hard of belief Uncle, by my troth
she is a whore.
Then thou art a knave:
7Negatur 7Argumentum Uncle.
7Probo 7tibi, Nephew:
He that knows a woman to be a quean must needs be a
knave, thou sayst thou knowest her to be one, 7ergo if she
be a
quean thou art a knave:
7Negatur, 7sequela 7maioris, Uncle, he that knows a woman
to be a quean, must needs be a knave, I deny that.
Lucre, and Wit-good, you are both villains, get you out of
my house:
Why didst not invite me to thy wedding dinner?
And are not you and I sworn perpetual friends before
witness sir, and were both drunk upon it.
Daintily abused you have put a junt upon me:
Ha, ha, ha:
A common strumpet?
Nay now you wrong her sir, if I were she I would have the
law on you for that, I durst depose for her,
she never had common
use, nor common thought.
Despise me, publish me I am your wife,
What shame can I have now but you will have part,
If in disgrace you share, I sought not you:
You pursued me, nay forced me,
Had I friends would follow it,
Less then your action has been proved a rape.
Brother?
Nor did I ever boast of lands unto
you,
Money or goods: I took a plainer course:
And told you true I had nothing,
If error were committed it was by you.
thank your own folly, nor has my
sin been so odious but
worse has been forgiven, nor am I so deformed that I
may challenge
the utmost power of any old man's love, she that tastes not
sin
before, twenty to one but she will taste it after: most
of you old
men are content to marry young Virgins and take that
follows, where marrying one of us, you both save a
sinner, and
are quit from a cuckold forever,
"And more in brief let this your best thoughts win,
"She that knows sin, knows best how to hate sin."
Cursed be all Malice, black are the fruits of spite,
And poison first their owners: O my friends,
I must embrace shame, to be rid of shame,
Concealed disgrace prevents a public name.
Ah Wit-good ah Theodorus,
Alas sir, I was pricked in conscience to see her well
bestowed, and where could I bestow her better than upon
your
pitiful worship: excepting but myself, I dare swear she is
a
Virgin, and now by marrying your Niece I have banished myself
forever from her, she is mine
Aunt now by my faith, and
there is no Meddling with mine Aunt you know, a sin against
my Nuncle.
Lo, Gentlemen, before you all.
In true reclaimed form I fall,
Henceforth forever I defy,
The Glances of a sinful eye,
Waving of Fans, which some suppose,
Tricks of Fancy, Treading of Toes,
Wringing of Fingers, biting the Lip,
The wanton gate the alluring Trip,
All secret friends and private meetings,
Close borne letters, and Bawds greetings,
Feigning excuse to women's Labours,
When we are sent for to the next Neighbours,
Taking false Physic, and never
start,
To be let blood, though sign be at heart,
Removing chambers, shifting beds,
To welcome Friends in husbands steads,
Then to enjoy, and you to marry,
They first served, while you must tarry,
They to spend and you to gather,
They to get and you to father,
These and thousand thousand more,
New reclaimed I now abhor.
Ah, here is a lesson Rioter for you.
I must confess my follies, I will down too.
And Here forever I disclaim,
The cause of youths undoing. Game:
Chiefly dice, those true outlanders,
That shake out Beggars, Thieves and Panders,
Soul wasting Surfeits, sinful Riots,
Queans Evils, Doctors diets.
Apothecaries Drugs, Surgeons Clysters,
Stabbing of arms for a common Mistress,
Riband favours, Ribald Speeches,
Dear perfumed Jackets, penniless breeches,
Dutch Flap dragons, healths in Urine,
Drabs that keep a man too sure in:
I do defy you all.
Lend me each honest hand, for here I rise,
A reclaimed man loathing the general vice.
So, so, all friends, the wedding dinner cools,
Who seem most crafty prove oft-times most fools.
